Post: "I've been struggling with self-harm for so long, and I finally decided to give up my blades to my boyfriend for safekeeping. It's like, I know I shouldn't be relying on this unhealthy coping mechanism anymore, but it's hard to let go of the only thing that's helped me feel in control when everything else seems to be falling apart. I'm trying to move forward and find healthier ways to deal with my depression, but it's scary to think that I might not be able to handle life's challenges without my blades. I guess this is what they mean by 'global attributional style' - the way we attribute meaning to events in our lives can either help us or hurt us. In this case, I'm trying to reframe my thinking and see that giving up my blades doesn't mean I'm weak or incapable, but that I'm strong enough to face my problems head-on and find new ways to overcome them."
Transferred_Post: "I've been working hard to overcome my reliance on self-harm as a coping mechanism. It's challenging, but I'm determined to find healthier ways to manage my depression. Recently, I've made progress by giving up my blades to my boyfriend for safekeeping. While it's difficult to let go of the only thing that's provided a sense of control during difficult times, I recognize that relying on this unhealthy mechanism isn't sustainable. Instead, I'm focusing on developing new coping strategies and seeking support from loved ones. It's empowering to acknowledge that I have the strength within myself to confront life's challenges head-on, without relying on harmful habits. This mindset shift is an example of a specific attributional style, where I'm attributing the cause of my progress to specific factors rather than generalizing it to my entire life."
